Title: Prove $\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\sin \sin x \,dx=0$ without using the fact that $\sin(x)$ is odd.
Content: Prove $$\large\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\sin (\sin x) \,dx =0$$ without using the fact that $\sin(x)$ is odd. Computing this in wolfram says that it is uncomputable, which leads me to believe that the only way to find this would be methods for solving definite integrals. I am wondering if it is possible with any other techniques such as DUIS or residues?
AcceptedAnswer:
Here is a very weird solution. Notice that for $s \in \Bbb{R}$, $$ \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \sin(s\sin x) \, dx = \Im \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \exp(is\sin x) \, dx. $$ Now it follows that \begin{align*}
\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \exp(is\sin x) \, dx
&= \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \exp(se^{ix}/2) \exp(-se^{-ix}/2) \, dx \\
&= \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \exp(se^{ix}/2) \cdot \overline{\exp(-se^{ix}/2)} \, dx \\
&= 2\pi \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \left\{ \frac{1}{n!}\left(\frac{s}{2}\right)^{n} \right\}\left\{ \frac{(-1)^{n}}{n!}\left(\frac{s}{2}\right)^{n} \right\} \\
&= 2\pi \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n}}{(n!)^{2}}\left(\frac{s}{2}\right)^{2n} \\
&= 2\pi J_{0}(s),
\end{align*} where $J_{0}$ is the Bessel function of the first kind. Here we only need the fact that $J_{0}(s) \in \Bbb{R}$ if $s \in \Bbb{R}$. Consequently we get $$ \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \sin(s\sin x) \, dx = 0 $$ and $$ \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \cos(s\sin x) \, dx = 2\pi J_{0}(s). $$ (Of course, now both two identities extend to all of $s \in \Bbb{C}$ by the principle of analytic continuation.)
